Aux:TextAnnotations.Aux:document_text: When the new law was introduced, independent and opposition newspapers withheld publication for a day in protest and hundreds of media workers protested outside the parliament building. "We hope that the Court of Appeals, when it considers the case, will overturn this verdict and uphold the right to media freedom,” said Amnesty International. “The authorities should cease using criminal defamation charges to harass journalists and prevent their reporting on matters of legitimate public interest.” Ibrahim Eissa will also stand trial on 31 March in a separate case on charges of spreading false information about President Mubarak’s health. He was one of four newspaper editors who were sentenced in 2007 under Article 188 of the Egyptian Penal Code, which stipulates that anyone who “malevolently publishes false news, statements or rumours that is likely to disturb public order", should be imprisoned for up to one year prison and pay a fine of 20,000 Egyptian Pounds. All four have remained at liberty pending the outcome of their appeal, the next session of which is scheduled for 5 April. Topics • Egypt • Justice Systems • Censorship and Freedom of Expression
